newsitem.title: FRANCE: French fraud probe widens, hits Bouygues giant.
newsitem.headline: French fraud probe widens, hits Bouygues giant.

text.p: The managing director of a subsidiary of French building giant Bouygues was placed under investigation on Thursday in a fraud probe, justice sources said.
Judge Jean-Marie Charpier questioned Philippe Chalendon in Versailles, outside Paris, for alleged misuse of corporate funds, the sources said.
They added that Charpier made clear Bouygues chairman Martin Bouygues could likewise be brought before him later on Thursday as chairman of the Saur subsidiary.
Chalendon is managing director of the maritime branch of Bouygues Offshore.

Police released Patrick Le Lay, the head of private television channel TF1, overnight after the businessmen were summoned on Wednesday for questioning in the probe into false invoices involving some 40 companies in the Paris area.
The custody order for Bouygues runs out at 2.30 p.m. (1330 GMT).

The probe focuses on some five million francs ($880,000) worth of allegedly false invoices made out by Cerail consultant firm for subsidiaries of Bouygues including Saur, TF1, Bouygues Offshore and Bouygues Diversifications.
Three managers of the group have already been placed under investigation by the judge.
